Although the content of the course is really good, there are several issues I'd like to highlight:
* the code is focused on deprecated Python 2. There are sections to update the code to Python 3, but having deprecated version of programming language is not what I would expect
* lots of URLs in examples from first 10 sections are not working anymore, course content is not updated. You have to search through Q&A section and all around the Internet to determine whether you made a typo in your code or website is more strict in security and the code simply doesn't work anymore
* sources are not available, you have to follow and code with teacher. Combining with bullet above it's a mystery when you can't reproduce website hacking and takes really lots of time to find the root cause.

This course was awesome. This course was amazing. Fair warning- it takes time and dedication to really get the focus necessary to grasp the concepts in this. If you don't have sufficient time to invest, this course will probably not work for you, or you won't get the most out of it. It took me at least a couple months (I wasn't keeping track) and I was studying it almost every night with what time I had available (ave 2-3 hours). It will save time if you are already pretty good at coding. I was definitely a beginner programmer in python, although not an absolute beginner because I had some concepts down, some simple VBA and a course I once took in college, but I never really truly programmed, nor used python. 

I learned so much in this course. I learned of course so much about Security and I learned so much about Python. Like I said I didn't know anything about python before. I didn't know about object oriented programming or classes, though I knew it was something that existed and that I wanted to learn. I cannot learn well by theory alone, so this course was great because I got to see what objects are in practice, not from a lecture, but through actual lines of code. I also learned a lot about security and vulnerabilities. I'm definitely going to take his other courses. 

One year ago I knew very little about computers. Since then I have taken several courses here on udemy and plan to continue. I've taken Mike Meyer's CompTia A+ and Network+ to get a grounding with the intent to continue on to more advanced courses in other areas, and I also am taking his Security+ course, though I took/am taking all of these more passively, listening while I drive. They form and formed a good foundation so you understand what's going on but this course on Python and Ethical hacking cannot be taken passively! I would actually often detour from the lesson to go research a concept he talked about or that was linked in some way with the lesson. 

But besides python and security, I learned a lot about Linux, both in general and in it's Kali manifestation. I also beefed up my scant knowledge  of VirtualBox/Virtualization and of Networking, setting up a server, and even got a toehold into HTML and JS- all stuff I want to go on to learn. I am so happy too that I made the switch to Linux. I am now a *Nix guy. I'm done with those other two OSs, to the extent possible. I started this course with my Best Buy computer, which is not crappy but is small with low storage- a 128GB SSD and an I3. I thought it was decent at the time but I did not intend it for anything. Then I bought an old but formerly advanced business computer on sale that was dated- a mere 4GB ram but with Windows 10. I learned how to dual boot that one with windows and Kali on the same drive. It was funny how much faster Kali went on the same machine compared to windows, though it was still too slow. I decided it's easier and more fun to learn when you have better equipment, so I bought a gaming laptop, though I'm not a gamer, on ebay: The most powerful machine I've ever owned, 16gb an I7 6th gen I think- 8 logical cores, and I installed on it a 500GB SSD (that also was a new experience for me). I installed Kali again on that and then installed the Kali virtual machine as well as other virtualmachines as suggested in the course. It was interesting because my computer has an NVIDIA graphics card and it doesn't play nice with Kali so each time I boot up I have to manually disable it in the startup script. Just figuring that out was a little victory for me. Trying to install a new driver crashed my machine before so it wouldn't boot, so I'm fine with this for the future- it's an added layer of security that someone would have to get through to get at my machine! But my main regret about the computer I bought is it's *only* 15 in, and the lighter plastic style, rather than 17in heavier bodied. Huge problems I know. I'm just sharing all this because all of this happened in the context of the course on my path to completing it. I had this good computer for most of it, just not at the beginning, and that makes a huge difference. I'd say you probably need at least 8GB ram if you're going to run a virtual machine. I also think it's kind of a good idea to lay a basic foundation but at the same time it's also good to tackle the harder subjects first. I feel like if I take other security and hacking courses- which I will, both from Zaid and from others, they won't be as challenging as this- not that it was challenging but it was time requiring and demanding of focus and attention to detail. This is a good place for me to be at now because maybe it will be more downhill from here. I plan though to take a python and AI course soon. I want to reinforce and strengthen my python skills. Now I just have to find useful applications for my growing skills. I like it because it's an intellectual challenge, like chess, but unlike chess, has much more utility. 

Also Zaid and his team were very fast and prompt at responding to questions posed in the lessons. This is important in a follow along course where some people may have run into coding errors or system errors so they coudln't get the results expected, so for debugging or troubleshooting purposes, I really appreciate the response time. Zaid did a great job of interweaving Python with ethical hacking concepts, each building and increasing in depth as you progress through the course. You learn some Kali, Python, and hacking strategies along with some general network principals.  Zaid introduces some Python modules that are powerful, including scapy, response, BeautifulSoup, and regex. 
Building a backdoor was the highlight for me and was my first (knowing) exposure to malware. An introduction to BeEF was the scariest. You'll know why if you take the course.

The course increases in pace. If you've followed closely, you should have no problems with it. The biggest time consumer isn't the material, but getting some modules to install on Kali. If you use the QnA, and Google, you can get through it. Zaid's team is responsive with answering questions. The class has what it calls "object oriented" sections, but they really only touch on creating and using classes. You'll find no inheritance, overloading of operators, or anything like that. 

Ultimately, I would recommend this class to pretty much anyone. Even if you're not into ethical hacking, this class is a great intro to Python. If you are into ethical hacking, you'll revel in the content. I have taken the class as a first step toward preparing for the OSCP and I consider it a great investment. Zaid doesn't give assignments, but offers general ideas and statements about how powerful the code is. Had there been more assignments, or at least some clearer ideas of how to take these concepts and apply them on a borader scale, I would have given this a full 5 starts. Otherwise, it's a solid 4.5. Great job Zaid! Can't wait to dig into more of your content.

Very comprehensive and well-structured course. Covers a huge amount of different different programs, tools and attacks. I really liked the instructor's teaching methods; he managed to explain difficult concepts in a simple manner. His way of teaching programming is fantastic! No boring examples that many programming pages use. This guy teaches Python from scratch by building amazing useful hacking tools. I was a complete rookie but I could follow along and make most of my programs work.

The course follows a clear and consistent pattern. First, there is a theoretical part explaining how the program or the attack works under the hood. After, there's the implementation part where the instructor codes the program from scratch and explains all the new concepts. Thus, it was easy to follow along.

The course gives you a great foundation with Python by teaching all the necessary fundamentals. It also teaches you tons of different libraries, so even if you had prior experience there is definitely something new to learn. 

The course support was also good. The instructors answered always within 15 hours as they promise.

The only negative thing I could find was that there were some outdated sections. Some installations didn't just work like in the videos and I could see from the comments that other students had struggled with same issues I had. For savvy computer wizards this isn't going to be the problem since they can troubleshoot the root cause of the problem, but for beginners this can be really painful.

I also wish that the virtual box installation and configuration was covered in more detail, or at least there were resources provided regarding its configuration. If you are a beginner and fail to configure the virtual box correctly, the course is useless because things don't work like they should. 

However, I highly recommend this course to everyone. Absolutely worth the money. You will definitely learn something new.

 I am half way through the course and still most of my code doesn’t work.

Having said all this, the idea of using Ethical hacking to teach python is a great idea, and Zaid’s method of teaching is fantastic, albeit, he misses some commentary on his actions. However, there are more holes in the average teabag that need to be filled, most notably, the lousy, sparse, vague and mostly useless response form the hired tutors. What would help – if the course providers have any integrity, is a link to the code for all of the projects. This could have been a great course, based on the course outline and description. I have been using Python for over 6 years now, so this review is coming from someone already understanding the language itself. If you are new to Python, stay far away from this course, as you will only get confused.

Why the bad rating? This course is using an outdated Python version and the support is horrible support, both of which completely reduce the value of this course. 

The creator of the course apparently wanted to "patch" an old course by adding some section that translate the code from Python 2 to Python 3, but support for questions regarding Python 3 is non-existent (you will always get "just use Python 2"). If you offer sections in Python 3 and advertise a "makeover" of the course, you should be willing and able to provide support in that language. I had the feeling that the teaching assistants really just did not want to go through the additional work to actually check any code. 

I am currently at Section 10 with a question that has been unresolved for some weeks now (even after frequent follow-ups from my side) and will be dropping this course, as it is just frustrating at this point.
